site.userAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_8_4) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/28.0.1500.71 Safari/537.36

ruleScore.desc: The sitespeed.io total rule score for all the pages.

criticalPathScore.desc: Do as little as possible within the HEAD tag so that the browser can start rendering a page as soon as possible (avoid DNS lookups and load CSS/JS files).

jsSyncInHead.friendlyName: Number of JS synchronously in head
jsSyncInHead.desc: Loading Javascript synchronously inside of the HEAD tag will slow down your page rendering. Just don't do it!

jsPerPage.friendlyName: Number of Javascript files per page
jsPerPage.desc: Few larger files are better when using HTTP 1.1. For HTTP 2.0 it is better with many small files from few domains.

cssPerPage.friendlyName: Number of CSS files per page
cssPerPage.desc: Few larger files are better when using HTTP 1.1. For HTTP 2.0 it is better with many small files from few domains.

imagesPerPage.desc: Avoid too many images because it will take time for them all to load.

cssImagesPerPage.friendlyName: Number of CSS images per page
cssImagesPerPage.desc: Few larger CSS images are better when using HTTP 1.1. For HTTP 2.0 it is better with many small files from few domains.

requests.desc: Fewer requests are always faster than many requests.

imageWeight.desc: The weight of images is important, because of mobile and slow networks, keep the size to a minimal.

jsWeight.desc: The weight of javascripts is important, because of mobile and networks, keep the size to a minimal.

cssWeight.desc: The weight of CSS is important, because of mobile and networks, keep the size to a minimal.

imageWeightPerPage.desc: Image weight are the largest part of a web page. Make sure they are compressed and as small as possible.

cssWeightPerPage.desc: Don't download large front-end framework CSS files when you only use small parts of it.

jsWeightPerPage.desc: Don't download large Javascript libraries when you only use small parts of it.

pageWeight.desc: The total size is really important because of slow mobile networks, keep the size small.

docWeight.desc: Keep the ducument at a reasonable size, it will make it possible for the browser to generate the page faster.

domElements.desc: Too many DOM elements means that the page is complex and will be slower to render.

spofPerPage.desc: A Single Point Of Failure is a asset that is loaded (usually) from another domain before the page starts rendering, meaning if the asset isn't loaded, the page will be broken/slow.

spofPages.desc: How many pages have a single point of failures (meaning if someone elses API/site is broken, it will break your page.

requestsWithoutExpires.desc: Requests shall always have expire headers, so that they can be cached by the browser.

timeSinceLastModification.desc: The time since a file was changed the last time. If it was long ago, please make sure the cache time is high!

assetsCacheTime.desc: How long time the assets are cached in the browser. Long time is good.

domainsPerPage.desc: Many domains means many DNS lookups and that means slower pages.

browserScaledImages.desc: Never scale images in the browser, that will slow down the rendering.

requestsWithoutGZipPerPage.desc: All text content (JS/CSS/HTML) can and should be sent GZiped so that the size is as small as possible.

domainLookupTime.desc: The time it takes to do the DNS lookup. Definition: domainLookupEnd - domainLookupStart

redirectionTime.desc: Time spent on redirects. Definition: fetchStart - navigationStart

serverConnectionTime.desc: How long time it takes to connect to the server. Definition: connectEnd - connectStart

serverResponseTime.desc: How long time does it take until the server respond. Definition: responseStart - requestStart

backEndTime.desc: The time it takes for the network and the server to generate and start sending the HTML. Definition: responseStart - navigationStart

pageDownloadTime.desc: How long time does it take to download the page (the HTML). Definition: responseEnd - responseStart

firstPaintTime.desc: This is when the first paint happens on the screen, reported by the browser.

domInteractiveTime.desc: The time the browser takes to parse the document, including the network time from the user's location to your server. Definition: domInteractive - navigationStart

domContentLoadedTime.desc: The time the browser takes to parse the document and execute deferred and parser-inserted scripts including the network time from the user's location to your server. Definition: domContentLoadedEventStart - navigationStart

pageLoadTime.desc: The time it takes for page to load, from initiation of the pageview (e.g., click on a page link) to load completion in the browser. Important: this is only relevant to some pages, depending on how you page is built. Definition: loadEventStart - navigationStart

frontEndTime.desc: The time it takes for the browser to parse and create the page. Definition: loadEventStart - responseEnd

site.userAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_8_4) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/28.0.1500.71 Safari/537.36

domainsPerPage.desc: Many domains means many DNS lookups and that means slower pages.

browserScaledImages.desc: Never scale images in the browser, that will slow down the rendering.

requestsWithoutGZipPerPage.desc: All text content (JS/CSS/HTML) can and should be sent GZiped so that the size is as small as possible.

domainLookupTime.desc: The time it takes to do the DNS lookup. Definition: domainLookupEnd - domainLookupStart

redirectionTime.desc: Time spent on redirects. Definition: fetchStart - navigationStart

serverConnectionTime.desc: How long time it takes to connect to the server. Definition: connectEnd - connectStart

serverResponseTime.desc: How long time does it take until the server respond. Definition: responseStart - requestStart

backEndTime.desc: The time it takes for the network and the server to generate and start sending the HTML. Definition: responseStart - navigationStart

pageDownloadTime.desc: How long time does it take to download the page (the HTML). Definition: responseEnd - responseStart

domInteractiveTime.desc: The time the browser takes to parse the document, including the network time from the user's location to your server. Definition: domInteractive - navigationStart

domContentLoadedTime.desc: The time the browser takes to parse the document and execute deferred and parser-inserted scripts including the network time from the user's location to your server. Definition: domContentLoadedEventStart - navigationStart

firstPaintTime.desc: This is when the first paint happens on the screen, reported by the browser.

pageLoadTime.desc: The time it takes for page to load, from initiation of the pageview (e.g., click on a page link) to load completion in the browser. Important: this is only relevant to some pages, depending on how you page is built. Definition: loadEventStart - navigationStart

frontEndTime.desc: The time it takes for the browser to parse and create the page. Definition: loadEventStart - responseEnd

site.userAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_8_4) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/28.0.1500.71 Safari/537.36

ruleScore.desc: The sitespeed.io total rule score for all the pages.

criticalPathScore.desc: Do as little as possible within the HEAD tag so that the browser can start rendering a page as soon as possible (avoid DNS lookups and load CSS/JS files).

jsSyncInHead.friendlyName: Number of JS synchronously in head
jsSyncInHead.desc: Loading Javascript synchronously inside of the HEAD tag will slow down your page rendering. Just don't do it!

jsPerPage.friendlyName: Number of Javascript files per page
jsPerPage.desc: Few larger files are better when using HTTP 1.1. For HTTP 2.0 it is better with many small files from few domains.

cssPerPage.friendlyName: Number of CSS files per page
cssPerPage.desc: Few larger files are better when using HTTP 1.1. For HTTP 2.0 it is better with many small files from few domains.

imagesPerPage.desc: Avoid too many images because it will take time for them all to load.

cssImagesPerPage.friendlyName: Number of CSS images per page
cssImagesPerPage.desc: Few larger CSS images are better when using HTTP 1.1. For HTTP 2.0 it is better with many small files from few domains.

requests.desc: Fewer requests are always faster than many requests.

imageWeight.desc: The weight of images is important, because of mobile and slow networks, keep the size to a minimal.

jsWeight.desc: The weight of javascripts is important, because of mobile and networks, keep the size to a minimal.

cssWeight.desc: The weight of CSS is important, because of mobile and networks, keep the size to a minimal.

imageWeightPerPage.desc: Image weight are the largest part of a web page. Make sure they are compressed and as small as possible.

cssWeightPerPage.desc: Don't download large front-end framework CSS files when you only use small parts of it.

jsWeightPerPage.desc: Don't download large Javascript libraries when you only use small parts of it.

pageWeight.desc: The total size is really important because of slow mobile networks, keep the size small.

docWeight.desc: Keep the ducument at a reasonable size, it will make it possible for the browser to generate the page faster.

domElements.desc: Too many DOM elements means that the page is complex and will be slower to render.

spofPerPage.desc: A Single Point Of Failure is a asset that is loaded (usually) from another domain before the page starts rendering, meaning if the asset isn't loaded, the page will be broken/slow.

spofPages.desc: How many pages have a single point of failures (meaning if someone elses API/site is broken, it will break your page.

requestsWithoutExpires.desc: Requests shall always have expire headers, so that they can be cached by the browser.

timeSinceLastModification.desc: The time since a file was changed the last time. If it was long ago, please make sure the cache time is high!

assetsCacheTime.desc: How long time the assets are cached in the browser. Long time is good.

domainsPerPage.desc: Many domains means many DNS lookups and that means slower pages.

browserScaledImages.desc: Never scale images in the browser, that will slow down the rendering.

requestsWithoutGZipPerPage.desc: All text content (JS/CSS/HTML) can and should be sent GZiped so that the size is as small as possible.

serverConnectionTime.desc: How long time it takes to connect to the server. Definition: connectEnd - connectStart

serverResponseTime.desc: How long time does it take until the server respond. Definition: responseStart - requestStart

backEndTime.desc: The time it takes for the network and the server to generate and start sending the HTML. Definition: responseStart - navigationStart

pageDownloadTime.desc: How long time does it take to download the page (the HTML). Definition: responseEnd - responseStart

firstPaintTime.desc: This is when the first paint happens on the screen, reported by the browser.

domInteractiveTime.desc: The time the browser takes to parse the document, including the network time from the user's location to your server. Definition: domInteractive - navigationStart

domContentLoadedTime.desc: The time the browser takes to parse the document and execute deferred and parser-inserted scripts including the network time from the user's location to your server. Definition: domContentLoadedEventStart - navigationStart

pageLoadTime.desc: The time it takes for page to load, from initiation of the pageview (e.g., click on a page link) to load completion in the browser. Important: this is only relevant to some pages, depending on how you page is built. Definition: loadEventStart - navigationStart

frontEndTime.desc: The time it takes for the browser to parse and create the page. Definition: loadEventStart - responseEnd
